bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, September 27, 1875

div1.p: Reed describes his military responsibilities. He assures Emilie Lawrence that she is above all others in his heart.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, September 27, 1875

opener.dateline:
Willet's Point,
New York Harbor,
Sept. 27th, 75.

div1.p:
Here
it is Monday morning, the
beginning of a new week, and
just the time, above all others,
when I should feel refresh
-ed in mind & body. But, I
assure you, unless my sen-
sations sadly deceive me,
that I am an exhausted
boy, scarcely able to keep
my eyes open. Whether I shall
be able to finish this let-
ter, remains to be seen.
One thing is very sure, and
that is, if there is anything
that can keep my mental
machinery in motion, it
is thinking of you, and if
there is any task that this
right hand delights to
perform, it is writing
to you. It may surprise
you to be told that I have
had some very hard work
to do, during the past week:
Strange as it may seem, an
army surgeon occassion-
ally has something to do;
and, in this instance, it
has all fallen on my
shoulders. Dr Byrne's is
absent, on a week's leave-
Dr Heger has not yet put
in an appearance, & in
fact is so very slow, in
obeying orders, that I have
almost abandoned all
hope of his ever coming-
As a consequence, I have
been left alone, to make
out reports, (something
less than a thousand to be
made out,) to attend to the
sick, etc. As it happens,
there are just one dozen
soldiers sick & almost
as many Children- Some
of the latter very sick,
& requiring my constant
attention- Add to this my
duties as caterer of the
mess, & you can under-
stand that I have my
hands well occupied-
Besides these few trivialities
I will have to change my
quarters, this week, so as
to give Dr Heger a res-
ting spot- You perceive,
at present, I am occu-
pying the surgeon's house
& have been doing so ever
since I have been at the
Post- Dr B. being a bachelor,
there was an abundance
of room, & he was glad
to share his house with
me, for the sake of my
company- (I confess that the
last statement seems in-
credible, & yet it is true.)
But Dr Heger has very
foolishly or wisely, I don't
know which, seen fit to
get married, & of course
would prefer to have his
dwelling all to himself-
Hence, I, unfortunate mor-
tal, must, like the Arab,
“strike my tent & steal away”.
I go, however, with a cheerful
spirit, inasmuch as my future
quarters are very comfor-
table. From reports that have
reached me, I don't think
that I shall occupy them
very long. I have been told that
the Surgeon General contem-
plates assigning the recently
appointed Asst. Surgeons
to permanent duty very
soon- My only fear is, that
my orders will come be-
fore I can get my leave-
Still there is nothing def-
inite to be ascertained on
the subject. I tell you this,
so that you may not be
disappointed, should I
not be able to come. Be
convinced, however, that I
shall let no chance escape
me of coming, for really, I
feel as if I hadn't seen
your darling face for, at
least, one year- You can lit-
tle know how anxious
I am to come to Murfrees-
boro- So much do I desire
to see you, if only for a few
days, that, were there no
other means of commun-
ication, I would gladly
walk every mile- How fleet
of foot I should be, know-
ing that there was such
an angel awaiting my
coming! Bless your darling
heart! You are dearer to
me every day of my life!
The “love,” which you say
“burns in my heart for
a moment,” is ever burn-
ing there, & day by day, its
blaze grows purer & brighter.
“Ficle”! I may be in all
things else, but not in that-
Oh! No! There am I stead-
fast,- fixed, & nought can
ever move me! What should
change me? The silly, light-
headed girls that one meets
wherever he goes? These
moths hovering about the
blaze of Fashion -- carried
away with the frivolities
of the day, & never evolving
one sound thought! Away
with the thought! What pleas-
ure and happiness could
I find in the society of
such creatures? None what-
ever- Ah! no! let me worship
some sweet, modest, sen-
sible, Christian woman, or
none at all- One whose pres-
ence could make home bright-
er, & could lessen, rather
than add to, life's toils! And
you, my darling Emilie, are
such an one! I desire no
brighter gem to deck my Crown
than your own sweet self-
You are my ideal of a woman
and the guiding star of
my life-!
div1.closer:
Whilst I, am
ever, your fond and
devoted Walter.
P.S. How does it happen that you
failed to write on Friday? No let-
ter has arrived, to-day, & hence
my disappointment is very
great- I did not think that
you last letter was to take
the place of your regular weekly
letter, but was rather an additional
favor which you had bestowed-
I am afraid that I was mistaken.
Tomorrow will decide- W.R.
